Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization of electrochemical sensor technology for pathogen detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
There are ongoing efforts to develop sensors to monitor for wound infections. The vast majority of smart-bandage research and development is focused on infection sensors based on general characteristics, such as pH, temperature, and gases. While simpler to implement, these general characteristics also fluctuate significantly and can change due to a large number of factors, resulting in unreliable identification. The current standard to monitor for wound infections relies on an initial human assessment, either patient or caregiver, of when an infection is developing. The decision is based on visual inspection, smell of the wound, and other patient symptoms, such as fever. When an infection is suspected, samples are collected from the wound and sent to a central facility for analysis. At the centralized facility, plate culturing is the gold standard for pathogen identification. The technique is simple, but requires 24 hours or more for identification.

This proposal aims to create, test, and disseminate electrochemical sensor technology for quantitative microbiological studies. Specifically, this approach will utilize micro-fabricated electrochemical sensors to rapidly and selectively detect molecules produced by bacteria. The detected molecules are uniquely produced by only certain species of cells; therefore, by detecting the molecules it is possible to determine which cells and how many of them are present in a sample. The proposed technology will allow caregivers to remotely monitor their patients and provide them with better care. In a hospital post-op or burn ward, rapid identification is the primary customer need, as wounds are monitored routinely, but require time-consuming tests when an infection is suspected to identify the pathogen. In the home, patients must determine on their own if they have an infection developing or wait until a home healthcare worker visits them. The proposed product could reduce the visit frequency for home healthcare professionals if the wounds are monitored remotely, decreasing the workload for an already overburdened and understaffed system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The commercialization potential of a sensor technology developed by the team during a prior NSF project was evaluated. The sensors can identify bacterial infection using molecules that bacterial cells excrete. Over 100 potential users were interviewed and it was determined that there is a significant need for this technology. Steps are now being taken to commercialize this technology.

Intellectual Merit: During the award period, a professor and graduate student learned about entrepreneurship and the commercialization process. This knowledge advances the academic community’s understanding of the procedure for translating technology from research labs to industry. This project also taught the team how to evaluate the potential impact of future research projects from an industry perspective.

The team confirmed that there is a substantial need for their sensor technology. New markets were identified for the technology during the evaluation process. Veterinarians as well as doctors can use these sensors to identify infections. Interviewing potential users also gave new information about what features and specifications are necessary for converting the technology into a successful product.

Broader Impacts: The professor and student are now sharing their knowledge with colleagues at their institution to encourage entrepreneurship and integration of feedback from potential users early into their research projects. The boarder impact of the technology evaluated by the team during the I-Corps program is potentially immense. Doctors and veterinarians will be able to identify at the point-of-care whether the patient has a bacterial infection and which species is causing the infection. This will allow care-givers to prescribe the correct antibiotic immediately, improving healthcare and saving money.
